Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The petition of Sandersville Railroad, as amended, is granted.
Document Sources.Source Justification: In April, Capital B reported that Thomas K. Bond, a hearing officer with the Georgia Public Service Commission, approved Sandersville’s request to move forward with condemning properties to construct their railroad spur.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: I would like to say this has been a long, difficult case, and I want to thank all the parties, and especially thank our staff for the diligence, hard work, and all the parties for just the professionalism and decorum shown on this case.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Shaw, the chairman of the board, provided the only comment

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: We’re determined to keep fighting against this attempt to take our ancestral land from us.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s, said in a statement

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: We want to keep our property whole, so we can pass it down to our children and they can continue to build generational wealth.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s, said in a statement

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: As Black people, ownership of land and property is more valuable than a dollar amount because it allows a certain type of economic freedom that we are often deprived of.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: attorney Sharika Robinson told Capital B last year

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: I don’t know what is ‘just’ about replacing that economic liberty with a dollar amount that will not increase in value.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: attorney Sharika Robinson told Capital B last year

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Georgia law does not permit a private company to take land through eminent domain unless the land will be put to a public use.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Building a rail spur that will only be used by a few private companies, and not the public at large, is not a public use.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: We look forward to making it clear to the court that the [Public Service Commission] made an error in considering Sandersville’s land grab as a public use.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The railroad project involves constructing a 4.5-mile rail spur to connect the Hanson Quarry, a rock mine owned by Heidelberg Materials, to a main train line along a nearby highway.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Benjamin Tarbutton III, the owner of Sandersville Railroad, has contended this development is expected to create 20 temporary construction jobs, a dozen permanent jobs with an average salary and benefits package of $90,000, and generate over $1.5 million annually for Hancock County

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The reality is if you’ve ever lived near a train, or you’ve ever ridden on a train or been near a train, it’s not the same as trucks driving by.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Jamie Rush, senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project who represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition, a coalition of residents who aren’t losing their property to the railroad but will be affected by the train

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Even if the train is not going through your property, the fact that a train is near your property — all of the noise pollution, the vibrations of a train … all of that affects your property value, your peace of mind and your home.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Jamie Rush, senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project who represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition, a coalition of residents who aren’t losing their property to the railroad but will be affected by the train

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: I truly hate to have to say this, but if David v. Goliath had been decided by the GA Public Service Commission, they’d have confiscated David’s slingshot and handed it to the Philistines,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Two weeks after the hearing, Georgia state Rep. Spencer Fyre sent a letter to the commission describing the land acquisition as a “heist attempt,” where private businesses are looking to increase their profits by taking folks’ land despite their resistance to sell.
